I'm asking specifically about implementations and their copyright, not the Ethereum trademark. Those are two separate issues; IMO the case that the legal ownership translates into any kind of real power is *much* weaker for the former than for the latter.

The open source licenses mean that usage of the ethereum clients is legal; they would have no case. The most they could do is hire devs to keep improving the client and put a closed license on *those improved versions*. But anyone could do that...

Even if all copyright ownership for all existing clients were to be transferred to Ethereum Hating Evil Corp, people can (i) still use the clients, because the existing open source licenses, and (ii) build new clients. So what can they do?
I don't see a plausible pathway for leveraging copyright ownership over individual ethereum implementations into any kind of political power over the ethereum protocol.
Fortunately the exist ethereum clients that are non-copyleft (MIT) licensed too.

OK I admit that the EF's ownership over the Ethereum trademark exists, and this is a sore point in public blockchain governance; @zooko has struggled with this too. Though at best that's control over the *name*, not the platform...

That's the terms of use for the *website*. There are multiple Ethereum clients, some of which are maintained by companies completely independent of the EF, eg. https://nethermind.io/. So there is no such thing as "the" Ethereum codebase.

To zoom back out to a more traditional context, "national defense is a public good" feels natural to say, "Canada is a public good" does not. (the parallel here is "http://tornado.cash, http://ethresear.ch, etc" <-> "national defense", "Ethereum as a whole" <-> "Canada")

Oh I know that CBDCs will be centralized and account-based. I'm wondering whether actions inside CBDCs are *provable to the outside world*. eg. Estonia e-residency is centralized, but is provable to ethereum.

A "yes" answer to my question would basically require ethereum to be able to run a light client of the CBDC (ie. verify some kind of signatures from the masternodes that verify a transaction's success).
"verifiable on ethereum" != "use ethereum". Bitcoin transactions for example are totally verifiable on ethereum, as there are BTC light clients that can run inside the ETH chain.

Important tech question about these CBDCs that are starting to pop up (CC @mg0314a): will transactions be cryptographically provable? That is, if I send you N coins, can I generate a cryptographic proof that this happened that can be verified on the ethereum chain? ...

Arguably it's whether or not the backing parties run bitcoin full nodes that matter; ethereum consensus nodes are there to verify ethereum transactions, it's a different task than managing the bridge, even though in liquid the parties responsible for the two tasks overlap

As far as "enterprise" use cases go, what does liquid being a sidechain even mean? Sidechain: different consensus, shared currency USDT on liquid: different consensus, different currency USDT on liquid has as much to do with bitcoin as USDT on ethereum has to do with bitcoin.

The real point is that we need to have more by-default segregation between a person's different activities in general. One address per dapp, and often more than one. If people want to link they can but they have to do so explicitly.

I think @ensdomains should make it a default to fund registering domains through http://tornado.cash. Though this would require web3 support for "generate a new address from the HD wallet" to work well....
Anyone new should probably use http://tornado.cash to move over 0.1 eth to a fresh address that they register their name with, so the rest of their activity is unlinked
And ethereum in 13 seconds.

Distributing *to* large-N nodes is not hard, bitcoin and ethereum do this already. Aggregating *from* large-N nodes and getting one node to verify everything without huge computational and bandwidth reqs is the harder thing.
Ethereum only slashes for unavailability in cases where >1/3 of other nodes are unavailable, and even there the penalties only slowly ramp up over the course of ~3 weeks.

Decentralization is a gradient, not an absolute. You mean to say Ethereum isn't as decentralized as Bitcoin. I don't dispute that, but which measure of decentralization are you using? Hashpower? Devs? Software and tooling? Hodler demographics? Geographic usage? Core developers?

It took my benchmark machine 9 days 2 hours to full sync Parity 2.6.8 to Ethereum block 9,390,000. It performed over 47 TB of disk reads and 42 TB of disk writes, was disk IO-bound the entire time.

It appears that new Parity Ethereum nodes won't do a full sync thanks to a stale bootnode list and incompatibility with Geth bootnodes due to not supporting EIP 2364. You have to manually pass in a reserved_peers file with compatible peer nodes in order to start syncing w/o warp.
